body:
I just had a longer think about this, and am wondering if instead the correct 'fix' is the other way around: update the mocks to produce bytes instead of strings.

The argument here is that by passing bytes from Spark through to the output we avoid any and all encoding issues. The only exception here is in `yarn-cluster` mode, where Airflow wants to detect the application id of the job that was submitted. In _this_ case the previous code would use a best effort to get it out: assume (hope?) the data was UTF-8 encoded (which is pretty reasonable) but only for the purpose of extracting the application id. In the case it was wrong, the original data was still passed through as-is and the only harm was that Airflow would miss the application id; the log data would still be fine.
The other exception is `logging.info(line)` inside `_process_log` which I _think_ needs strings? (I see you removed the `Output: {}, Stderr: {}` interpolations on the error case in your PR)

Ah, logging. You're correct. I forgot we're prefixing stuff. (And yup, I removed the interpolation from the exception. Spark is normally pretty verbose, and including it in the exception string when we've just logged it all anyway seemed… not terribly useful.)

With respect to pipe buffering, I think the default depends on the python version: from 3.3.1 (& 3.2.6) it's -1, but before that it was 0. Either way we should specify it to ensure consistent behaviour.
Oh yes, good catch, default on py2 is 0 (unbuffered) which is probably not what we want. I'll put that back in.

1. Why would you need to change all operator code (airflow.operator.*) to change its logger? It will inherit it from TaskInstance (I think), if not you could use "propagate = True" in the logging config and set "airflow.operators". Or add an extra method called something like "setTaskInstance" to TaskHandler, as they operators will inherit the parent logger. Obviously we need to try this out. I wouldn't necessarily call it critical as these kind of changes could be acceptable.

2. I think you would need to grab the template from the configuration and not do it in TaskHandler 'fixed'. Arguments from the config are password as keyword arguments to the constructor of the Handler. https://docs.python.org/2/library/logging.config.html#logging-config-dictschema

3. I don't think that really matters. You can just iterate over logging.handlers and see if one exposes the ReadMixin (or read method) and you are fine: they are logging all the same information. You could also make this a configuration item in airflow.cfg, i.e. Handler to use to read the logs.

I would use the flush method for uploading (https://github.com/python/cpython/blob/2.7/Lib/logging/__init__.py#L770), but that's arguable.

I think you don't you need to close the handlers by hand, I presume these are closed on interpreter shutdown. But that can be tested of course.
@aoen, thanks for your PR! By analyzing the history of the files in this pull request, we identified @mistercrunch, @bolkedebruin and @jlowin to be potential reviewers.

@bolkedebruin 
1. Operators (at least majority) uses **root logger** like `logging.info` instead of logging into a specific logger. How can it be changed to use 'airflow.task' logger for all operators?
2. Would you be able to provide a concrete example? Given a task_instnace, how can we provide this task instance context when we use `dictConfig(CONFIG)` to instantiate handler and get the logger.
3. Why does it not matter? If webserver only grabs a random one and call the read method, it won't return the correct log unless user only configures one handler with the `read` method. But I guess we could make user specify in `airflow.cfg` the name of the handler. 

Max and I discussed using the configuration style today. This configuration is ultimately static and doesn't provide enough context when instantiating the handler (unless the second point is addressed). Ideally, we can use a log handler generator that returns a callable handler. It can then be instantiated during run time with task instance and other contexts as arguments. Then config dictionary would not be used in this design but might be used in each handler's implementation. I will sketch this new design out soon.

Here are several TODOs mentioned in the solution:

2. Airflow has many places trying to setup logging, including `airflow.cfg`, `setting.py configure_logging`, `cli.py setup_logging`. Those need to be refactored somehow. 
3. `AirflowTaskHandler` should be further break down into `S3TaskHandler` and `GCSTaskHandker` that extends from AirflowTaskHandler with different `close` and `read` method.

Hi @bolkedebruin,

Thank you for your interest :). Openshift is definitely one system we want to work for (we will have a cinder integration by default which should help that integration).

Unfortunately, while the meeting was recorded, the recording software didn't work correctly and we were unable to save the recording. However, we took fairly good notes of the meeting that I will post to the wiki page. I will be presenting this to another section of the kubernetes community soon and will be certain to post a link to the airflow dev mailing list/record the meeting.

Do you think that there would be interest among the airflow community for me to propose a more airflow-centric meeting? I didn't want to overstep any bounds by proposing one without consulting any airflow committers or PMCs.

@AllisonWang Some further thoughts on your No 1 (redirecting other logs), if logging is properly configured in the operators/task_runners etc (e.g. logging.getLogger(__name__) ), it is just a matter of correctly configuring the handler in the logging config to point to the TaskHandler. This will work as it will get the reference to the same logger that does have set_context, by python logging design.

@dimberman I think there will definitely be more interest. Especially augmented with some use cases to augment the discussion it will make it pretty attractive I guess. Don't worry about us committers. There is no bounds to doing meetups etc. We don't hold such a monopoly (and wouldn't want to).
@yk5 I think some docs would be good. Feel free to send them. :)

How would log rotate address this issue? 1 failing task is logging an excessive amount of data, and you won't even be able to see that log at all in the webserver because it just hangs. In that case, you'd have to manually find that log file from the airflow box. 

Log rotating would address the disk space issue, but I think webserver hanging is by far the bigger problem and I don't think that's addressed.

@s-cotter,

> Is there are reason to implement SFTP as a operator rather than hook like the existing ftp hook ? 

Yes, in this addition that uses paramiko library for ssh, SFTP is seen as one of the operator, that works on top of SSH Transport.  Also by the philosophy of airflow, the way i understood, I would use hooks to manage the underlying connections and operators to actually perform any functions using that hook. Although I am seeing mixups in hooks & operator at some places in current code.

> It would be nice to just be able to switch hooks (ftp->sftp) and have the same interface/functionality. In my case I need other features needed by the ftp hook for SFTP.

Sure, that would be good flexibility to have, but Paramiko is all about secure connections using ssh trasport, and dont support ftp or ftp over SSL/TLS. Although since it provides most of standard ftp functions in its sftp implementation ( ex: getCWD() ), we can create wrapper functions in SFTPOperator, if the compatibility and easy switching between ftp and sftp is needed. That would be a separate change though and out of the scope of this PR.

@bolkedebruin Make sense to me. Both jobs and task runner uses LoggingMixin which returns logger with format `module_name.class_name`. We can set `propagate = True` to make logs go through parent log handlers. Setting up context for task_runner is easy but for jobs, we don't have a TI object to pass in the handlers. Actually, do we even want to display the logs from `models.py` or `jobs.py` to UI? Airflow users are more concerned about everything happening inside `task_runner` while other logs are mainly for debugging airflow itself. Can we maybe have a separate handler for those system logs?

Hi zhangela indeed excessive logs will make webserver hang for long time. This problem will be addressed later as we change the frontend to lazyly fetch the logs. Truncating logs shouldn't be part of airflow core logic. You can maybe make task logging less verbose or change LOG_LEVEL in airflow config.
I see. Yeah I think as long as the webserver can lazily fetch the logs 1 page at a time, that would solve the main problem here. Any idea when that would be shipped?
@ronfung, thanks for your PR! By analyzing the history of the files in this pull request, we identified @mistercrunch, @bolkedebruin and @aoen to be potential reviewers.
@bolkedebruin @aoen thoughts on this?

I think we should close this, we are putting together a more detailed proposal for logging here:
https://github.com/apache/incubator-airflow/pull/2422 which will include this functionality

> I'm not sure if I completely agree with the logic (or completely understand it from reading it). 

The only logic change is to make a Backfill run the number of dag runs that fit within the `max_dag_runs` limit, which I think seems reasonable as it makes Backfill jobs consistent to what the limit is for.

>If we are able to run within max_dag_runs limits we should be able to run the whole backfill in one go

This is still the case, no change is done as `_process_backfill_task_instances` would receive all the tasks to run, same as the `while` loop implementation withing `_exectue` as before.

>, just a little bit slower: if a dag run finished a new slot becomes available, backfills wait till all runs finish so most likely they will get a slot except when the scheduler runs a new dag run. So what is the expected behavior? Do we wait till a slot becomes available (timeout needed?)? Do we expect the user to issue another backfill (might be confusing to the user).

All these are interesting questions, but I think they're out of scope of this PR - since these changes only try to enforce the `max_active_runs` limit correctly within a `BackfillJob`.

IMO any wait/retry logic should be made external to the `BackfillJob`, e.g. in the CLI running BackfillJobs for the same date interval or providing the user with `--tries` param or something alike. Including wait/retry logic within `BackfillJob` would only make it more complex and harder to maintain, test and debug.

Backfill is already a manual adhoc process run in the CLI, so as long as proper logging is provided to the user, they should be already aware of the `max_active_runs` limit, so providing some parameter which helps them decide how long to wait could be a good solution.

As of now, with this PR, the user would see that not all dag runs were able to run since the limit has been reached, and she's advised to re-run the backfill job.

> In addition, as this is a huge PR, please stay in scope and don't fix details outside its scope (no changes to dagrun_exists, logging fixes etc). This makes it harder it rollback if required, besides you could introduce bugs that are unrelated.
>
> I prefer a PR that splits the refactor and the new functionality - again easier to review also considering the above remarks (and agreeing with @aoen) and easier to rollback if required.

Agreed, I've changed the branch to include two commits now:
- the first with no logic changes and just the refactor of the code within `BackfillJob._execute` to functions within the same class. Refactor is within scope as it only modifies parts of the previous `_execute` method and only touches `{airflow,tests}/jobs.py`
- the second with the change in logic to restrict dag runs in backfill job to the `max_active_runs` limit.
